prior_works.title: Flow Matching for Generative Modeling
prior_works.authors: Ricky T. Q. Chen, George Papamakarios, Jonathan Ho, Tim Salimans, Prafulla Dhariwal, Djork-Arné Clevert, Patrick Esser
prior_works.role: Foundational theory for rectified/flow-based generative models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: DNAEdit leverages the flow-matching/velocity-field formulation—predicting a time-dependent velocity to transport Gaussian noise to data—which enables estimating per-timestep velocities and motivates aligning the underlying Gaussian noise directly rather than relying on step-to-step latent approximations.

prior_works.title: Rectified Flow: A Straightening Method for Probability Flow ODEs
prior_works.authors: Shengmeng Liu, Jianfei Chen, Shuang Li, Jun Zhu
prior_works.role: Key RF formulation used for efficient sampling and linear noise–data interpolation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: DNAEdit explicitly exploits the RF property that noised latents lie on linear interpolations between Gaussian noise and clean images, using this structure to correct the base noise via velocity-informed adjustments and avoid accumulation along reversed trajectories.

prior_works.title: Denoising Diffusion Implicit Models (DDIM)
prior_works.authors: Jiaming Song, Chenlin Meng, Stefano Ermon
prior_works.role: Deterministic diffusion ODE sampling and inversion baseline
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The common practice of DDIM-style inversion—progressively adding noise and approximating future latents—motivates DNAEdit’s shift to noise-domain alignment to mitigate the reconstruction drift that DDIM inversions accumulate over timesteps.

prior_works.title: SDEdit: Image Synthesis and Editing with Stochastic Differential Equations

prior_works.relationship_sentence: DNAEdit inherits the training-free editing paradigm of re-noising for controllable edits, while addressing SDEdit-style error accumulation by directly aligning the Gaussian noise using RF velocities rather than iteratively approximating next-step latents.

prior_works.title: Prompt-to-Prompt Image Editing with Cross-Attention Control

prior_works.relationship_sentence: While Prompt-to-Prompt controls semantics via cross-attention, DNAEdit complements this line by improving the fidelity backbone of text-guided editing—reducing trajectory drift through noise alignment—so attention-based controls can operate on accurately reconstructed latents.

prior_works.relationship_sentence: DNAEdit targets the same reconstruction-gap problem as Null-Text Inversion but achieves it without per-image textual optimization, instead aligning the underlying Gaussian noise per timestep using RF velocities to curb cumulative inversion error.

prior_works.relationship_sentence: The observed drift in standard inversions that Edit‑Friendly DDPM Inversion seeks to remedy directly motivates DNAEdit’s strategy; DNAEdit departs from schedule tweaks and instead performs principled, velocity-guided noise-domain alignment in the RF setting.

synthesis_narrative:
DNAEdit’s core insight—aligning the Gaussian noise directly in the rectified-flow (RF) noise domain to reduce inversion drift—emerges from two converging threads: text-guided, training-free editing and flow-based generative modeling. Flow Matching and Rectified Flow establish a velocity-field formulation in which noisy latents follow straight-line interpolations between Gaussian noise and data. This linear structure is precisely what DNAEdit exploits: instead of reconstructing by traversing (and approximating) future latents step by step, it estimates the RF velocity at each time and corrects the base noise itself to stay on the exact path.
In training-free editing, SDEdit and DDIM inversion popularized re-noising and deterministic ODE inversions for real-image edits, but both suffer from cumulative trajectory error when the current noisy latent is used to predict later ones. Subsequent inversion works—Null-Text Inversion and Edit-Friendly DDPM Inversion—explicitly tackle reconstruction drift, either via per-image optimization of guidance tokens or tailored schedules, underscoring the centrality of error accumulation in practical editing. DNAEdit addresses this same bottleneck with a different mechanism: noise-domain correction grounded in RF velocities, obviating per-image textual optimization and reducing dependence on fragile step-to-step approximations. Finally, prompt-level control methods like Prompt-to-Prompt provide semantic steering that is complementary to DNAEdit’s fidelity improvements, which ensure attention-based edits are applied to accurately reconstructed latents. Together, these works directly inform DNAEdit’s design: adopt RF’s linear transport and velocity estimation, retain training-free text guidance, and neutralize inversion drift by aligning the Gaussian noise at each timestep.
